body: Great!  I'll review this tomorrow and will give you some concrete feedback.  A few points will be similar to issues we've seen with the [Cython PR](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/1770) but are very easy to address; mainly we need to protect both the test suite and the main file with a couple of checks so that this code is simply skipped in environments without the rpy2 libraries instead of erroring out.
Is there an accepted way to write docstrings for magics which include tests?

@jonathan-taylor, we don't do too much doctesting in IPython, leaving the docstrings mostly to contain illustrative examples rather than contort them into also being tests.  so you can feel free to copy/paste from a session into an example block as the [numpy docstring standard](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/doc/HOWTO_DOCUMENT.rst.txt#docstring-standard) suggests.  In order to avoid it being doctested, simply add the `@skip_doctest` decorator from IPython: `from IPython.testing.skipdoctest import skip_doctest`.

Use the command `iptest`, which by default runs the whole test suite.  But it's a thin wrapper around nose, so you can pass it any valid nose flags.  In particular, while developing it's convenient to just run the tests you're working on, so you can call `iptest IPython.extensions.tests.test_rmagic` and it will only cover your tests.
[Here](http://ipython.org/ipython-doc/stable/development/testing.html) is a bit more info on how the testing machinery is set up, let us know if any of it isn't clear and we'll be happy to help out.

Not available for testing:
Those two failures are just from lacking isolation in the test suite.  I'll make a small PR against your branch with the fix, so you don't have to go spelunking in our test machinery.

This is looking great, thanks @jonathan-taylor for the work, and everyone else for the review!  Jonathan, I think once these few issues are dealt with (and see my out-of-band fix for the test isolation issue), we'll be able to merge it.  The cython one should also land soon, so very shortly we'll have built-in cython and R from IPython!

Not available for testing:

@jonathan-taylor, just so you know: this is producing a merge conflict now, because a test for pygments arrived in the meantime.  But the problem is trivial to fix, I'll send you a patch out of band so you don't have to deal with the git conflict.

Actually, I'm not sure how to create a patch that corresponds to a rebase, but the rebase itself is in this case trivial to do, and it will be useful knowledge in any case :)

Just type

```
git rebase master
```

It will then warn you of a conflict in `iptest.py`.  Edit that file, and you'll find at line 148 and following, this:

```
<<<<<<< HEAD
have['pygments'] = test_for('pygments')
have['wx'] = test_for('wx')
have['wx.aui'] = test_for('wx.aui')
=======
>>>>>>> Ensure that no tests are attempted if numpy or rpy2 are not present.
```

Change that to read:

```
have['pygments'] = test_for('pygments')
```

that is, simply remove the `<<<, ===, >>>` markers as well as the two `wx` lines, and save

Then type

```
git add IPython/testing/iptest.py  # or appropriate relative path
git rebase --continue
```

and you should be done.  You'll have to force-push your changes since this rewrites history:

```
git push --force
```

and the PR will update with the new code and will become mergeable again.

Sorry for the confusion with the conflict, it was actually caused by my fix :)

BTW Jonathan, regarding the docstrings, I see we have some extra `\\` at the end in code blocks in docstrings [like the `%run` one](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/core/magics/execution.py#L328).  I don't recall exactly why we did that (it could have been for the latex manuals) but you could test to see if that helps.

I've tried to adjust things after the helpful feedback, though I think I may have messed things up in trying to run through Fernando's rebase suggestion so I'd like to walk back that last commit.

Changes:
- %R will return None if the value is NULL
- In line mode, it will not return anything if the last element of line.split(';') printed something to the console, as detected by flush().
- I've added the str_to_unicode converters.
- I added the possibility of caching the display_data of one call to %R. I have a use case in mind, but maybe this should be an argument to R? Any opinions?

- Yes, that last commit should probably be removed, as it's absolutely huge. 
- I see that the final diff accidentally removes the line `have['pygments'] = test_for('pygments')` in `iptest.py`.
- Note that you committed the example notebook [with conflict markers in it](https://github.com/jonathan-taylor/ipython/blob/6f7e6ebc9241061c93854ec3129f5a10b97eb13a/docs/examples/notebooks/rmagic_extension.ipynb#L64), so the file is corrupted and can't be loaded.  You'll need to remove those.

Let me know if you need a hand with the rebase, I don't want this to be obnoxiously complicated for you...

A remark about the use of data.frames/numpy structured arrays. A structured array is converted to a data.frame as expected:

``` python
In [1]: %load_ext rmagic

In [2]: import numpy as np
   ...: datapy = np.array([(1, 2.9, "a"),(2, 3.5, "b"), (3, 2.1, "c")], dtype = [('x', int),('y', float), ('z', 'S1')])
   ...: datapy
   ...: 
Out[2]: 
array([(1, 2.9, 'a'), (2, 3.5, 'b'), (3, 2.1, 'c')], 
      dtype=[('x', '<i4'), ('y', '<f8'), ('z', '|S1')])

In [3]: %%R -i datapy
   ...: print(datapy)
   ...: 
  x   y z
1 1 2.9 a
2 2 3.5 b
3 3 2.1 c
```

But when you send a data.frame back to python, you get:

``` python
In [7]: %%R -o datar
   ...: datar <- datapy
   ...: print(datar)
   ...: 
  x   y z
1 1 2.9 a
2 2 3.5 b
3 3 2.1 c

In [8]: datar
Out[8]: 
array([['1', '2', '3'],
       ['2', '3', '2'],
       ['a', 'b', 'c']], 
      dtype='|S1')
```

You don't get a structured array (so all data are casted to the same type, string in this case), but even more unexpected the array seems transposed. I think this could be very confusing for users. But maybe it has to do with rpy2 and not with this (for the rest wonderfull!) rmagic?

I didn't notice the transpose. This may have to do with a C/Fortran indexing issue

%%R matrix(c(1,2,3,4,5,6),3,2)

In [7]:

%%R print(matrix(c(1,2,3,4,5,6),3,2))
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    4
[2,]    2    5
[3,]    3    6

In [8]:

np.array((1,2,3,4,5,6)).reshape((3,2))
Out[8]:
array([[1, 2],
       [3, 4],
       [5, 6]]) 

I did punt on converting dataframes for the time being, with the intent of trying to integrate with pandas in the near future.

There is an issue about this in rpy2 for a while, but not yet resolved (https://bitbucket.org/lgautier/rpy2/issue/44/numpyrecarray-as-dataframe). But there is a possible solution mentioned in the issue with np.records.fromarrays.
I tried it with al little hack in Rpull:

``` python
 def Rpull(self, line):
        outputs = line.split(' ')
        for output in outputs:
            if self.r("is.data.frame({0})".format(output))[0]:
                self.shell.push({output:np.rec.fromarrays(self.r(output), names = tuple(self.r(output).names))})
            else:
                self.shell.push({output:self.Rconverter(self.r(output))})
```

and this lets me do:

```
In [5]: %R print(datar)
  x   y z
1 1 2.9 a
2 2 3.5 b
3 3 2.1 c

In [6]: %Rpull datar

In [7]: datar
Out[7]: 
rec.array([(1, 2.9, 'a'), (2, 3.5, 'b'), (3, 2.1, 'c')], 
      dtype=[('x', '<i4'), ('y', '<f8'), ('z', '|S1')])
```

So it seems working (it only returns a record array, and I would prefer a normal structured array). I suppose this is a too simple hack (as I don't understand all the complexity of the code), but maybe you can do something with it.

Thanks for the hack. It seems to work now, at least for this example -- I just added an addition call to np.asarray (which is what self.Rconverter defaults to presently).

In [7]: datapy= np.array([(1, 2.9, 'a'), (2, 3.5, 'b'), (3, 2.1, 'c')], 
      dtype=[('x', '<i4'), ('y', '<f8'), ('z', '|S1')])

In [8]: %R -i datapy

In [9]: %%R -o datar
datar = datapy
   ...: 

In [10]: datar
Out[10]: 
array([(1, 2.9, 'a'), (2, 3.5, 'b'), (3, 2.1, 'c')], 
      dtype=[('x', '<i4'), ('y', '<f8'), ('z', '|S1')])

Since these seem to be a bit subtle, could you perhaps add some of those cases to the test suite?  That will ensure that the problem doesn't reappear later on a refactoring or other changes, for one thing...

After playing with the structured array conversion a little, I realized that this might try to convert almost every return value to a structured array which doesn't seem ideal as structured arrays are harder to work with than ordinary ndarrays (even when all fields have the same dtype). 

So, I've added the option to try to convert things to structured arrays, with a -d flag to R and a -d flag to Rpull. I also add a new magic, Rget which is like Rpull except it returns the value rather than pushing it to shell.user_ns.

Tiny error:

```
File "/home/fperez/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/IPython/extensions/rmagic.py", line 555
    RGET_DOC = ' '*8 + RMagics.Rget.__doc__
           ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

you're missing a comma in the previous line.

In trying to run the code in the notebook, I'm getting an error b/c I don't have the 'lars' R package.  Would it be possible to have the illustrative notebook run only with the functionality that's built into R?  Since it's meant only to teach the basics of using the magic, I would prefer if it runs on a vanilla R install (esp. since I couldn't find lars even in the fairly extensive ubuntu R package list).

Other than that, and the unicode issue with exceptions which [is not really your problem here](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1827), I think this is looking very good.  At this point I think we're starting to hit diminishing returns for keeping it in review.  

Unless you have anything major in mind, I'd be happy to merge it once you can fix the example notebook to load without requiring additional packages and fix the missing comma.  How does that sound?

Sorry for the redundant comment, I was a little bit slower than Fernando ..
But I noticed something with the Error Handling. If you gèt an error, the next time you use the magic, you get the last part of the error again. Like:

``` python
In [61]:  %R not_existing

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RMagicError                               Traceback (most recent call last)
...

RMagicError: parsing and evaluating line "not_existing". R traceback: "Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos) : object 'not_existing' not found
"

In [62]:  %R print("This does work")

Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos) : object 'not_existing' not found
[1] "This does work"
```

So this seems double, however, if you get more messages, eg an error and a warning, only the first is printed when the line is executed, and all messages are printed the next time you use %R (and in this example it includes usefull information, namely which file wasn't found):

``` python
In [65]: %R source("/data/PhD/IDEAsvn/trunk/R/ona_processing.R")
...
RMagicError: parsing and evaluating line "source("/data/PhD/IDEAsvn/trunk/R/ona_processing.R")". R traceback: "Error in file(filename, "r", encoding = encoding) : 
  cannot open the connection
"

In [66]: %R print("This does work")

Error in file(filename, "r", encoding = encoding) : 
  cannot open the connection
In addition: Warning message:
In file(filename, "r", encoding = encoding) :
  cannot open file '/data/PhD/IDEAsvn/trunk/R/ona_processing.R': No such file or directory
[1] "This does work"
```
Ah, you also saw the error thing. So the first part of my comment is resolved, but the second part not yet. Now you don't get the warning at all.

For now, I've included the flushed error message in stdout. We now see the stderr twice, once in the exception and once in the flushed stdout. Maybe capturing stderr separately would solve this, but at least the message is intercepted.

## In [2]: %R source("nothing.R")

RMagicError                               Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-87eb6ea5bbe6> in <module>()
----> 1 get_ipython().magic(u'R source("nothing.R")')

/Users/jonathantaylor/ipython/IPython/core/interactiveshell.pyc in magic(self, arg_s)

   2130         magic_name = magic_name.lstrip(prefilter.ESC_MAGIC)
-> 2131         return self.run_line_magic(magic_name, magic_arg_s)
   2132 
   2133     #-------------------------------------------------------------------------

/Users/jonathantaylor/ipython/IPython/core/interactiveshell.pyc in run_line_magic(self, magic_name, line)
   2055                 args.append(sys._getframe(stack_depth).f_locals)
   2056             with self.builtin_trap:
-> 2057                 result = fn(*args)
   2058             return result
   2059 

/Users/jonathantaylor/ipython/IPython/extensions/rmagic.pyc in R(self, line, cell)

/Users/jonathantaylor/ipython/IPython/core/magic.pyc in <lambda>(f, _a, *_k)
    188     # but it's overkill for just that one bit of state.
    189     def magic_deco(arg):
--> 190         call = lambda f, _a, *_k: f(_a, *_k)
    191 
    192         if callable(arg):

/Users/jonathantaylor/ipython/IPython/extensions/rmagic.pyc in R(self, line, cell)
    487         if line_mode:
    488             for line in code.split(';'):
--> 489                 text_result, result = self.eval(line)
    490                 text_output += text_result
    491             if text_result:

/Users/jonathantaylor/ipython/IPython/extensions/rmagic.pyc in eval(self, line)
    143             warning_or_other_msg = self.flush() # otherwise next return seems to have copy of error
    144             raise RMagicError(unicode_to_str('parsing and evaluating line "%s".\nR traceback: "%s"\n R stdout:"%s"\n' %
--> 145                                              (line, str_to_unicode(exception.message, 'utf-8'), warning_or_other_msg)))
    146         text_output = self.flush()
    147         ri.set_writeconsole(old_writeconsole)

RMagicError: parsing and evaluating line "source("nothing.R")".
R traceback: "Error in file(filename, "r", encoding = encoding) : 
  cannot open the connection
"

In addition: Warning message:
In file(filename, "r", encoding = encoding) :
